pasuk.text: Nehemiah wrote this book from here on.

This refers to the twentieth year of King Darius, who is identical with Artaxerxes. In Tractate Rosh Hashanah (3a, b), we find that the phrase “the twentieth year” is mentioned twice using similar wording [to teach us that it is speaking of the identical year]. It states below (2:1), “And it came to pass in the month of Nissan of the twentieth year of Artaxerxes, etc.” The years were calculated from the month of Tishrei. It says here, “And it was in the month of Kislev of the twentieth year, etc.” This refers to the Kislev coming after Tishrei. Further down it says (2:1), “And it was in the month of Nissan of the twentieth year, etc.” This refers to the Nissan of the same year. And I cannot explain that they calculated their years from the month of Nissan and that the incident mentioned below: “And it was in the month of Nissan, etc.” occurred before this incident: “And it was in the month of Kislev, etc.” It is true that events [in the Torah] are not necessarily recorded in chronological order. Nevertheless, the chapters indicate that the second chapter took place only because of the events of the first chapter.
one of my companions.

text.title: and I asked them about the Jews:

pasuk.text: I asked them about the Jews who had escaped the Babylonian captivity and remained in Jerusalem.
because they were saved from the Babylonian exile.
And I asked them about the city.
They answered my first question first and my latter question last; first, concerning the Jews and afterwards, concerning the wall and the gates.
Those Jews who remained in the province of Jerusalem are in great trouble and reproach because the gentiles plunder and pillage them.

text.title: and the wall of Jerusalem is breached:

pasuk.text: And the wall of the city is breached, and the gates are burned with fire as they were before, for Israel had not built the wall of the city or its gates, only the Temple.
Heb. נִצְתוּ, like נֻצְתוּ.
Heb. יָמִים, many days.
Heb. אָנָא, an expression of request and supplication.
Heb. קַשֶּׁבֶת, like קוֹשֶּׁבֶת, listening, for just as one says from אוֹהֵב, אָהַב, so does one say from קָשַּׁב, קוֹשֵּׁב and קוֹשֶּׁבֶת.

Heb. חֲבֹל, a noun, an expression of corruption, since the “heth” is vowelized with a “hataf pattah,” and I cannot interpret it as a verb form, because in that case, it would have to be vowelized with a large “kamatz.”
Heb. חָבַלְנוּ, an expression of corruption, as in Daniel (6:23): “I have done no harm.”
like the matter that is stated (Deut. 30:4): “If your exile is at the end of the heavens, etc.”

text.title: I beseech You, O Lord, may Your ear now be attentive:

pasuk.text: At the beginning of his prayer he used this expression, and so after his prayer.
This is what he prayed for himself.
before the king.
Heb. מַשְּׁקֶה, like (Gen. 40:1): “… the butler of (מַשְּׁקֶה) the king of Egypt.” This is what I explained above (Ezra 2:63) according to the words of our Sages, that Hattirshatha is Nehemiah.
That was Darius, and because of his kingship he was called this.
They brought wine before the king in the court.

And I carried the cup of wine and gave it to the king, and so is the custom, that the one who brings wine into the king’s court does not carry it and give it to the king, but the chief butler receives it from the hand of the one who brings it, and carries it and gives it to the king.

text.title: And I had never been sad in his presence:

pasuk.text: And I was not accustomed to being sad in his presence, to have a sad face, but to be happy and cheerful, but now I was sad with a sad face.
Is it not so that you are not ill?
This incident is only wickedness of heart, that you have in your heart to put me to death by poisoning this cup.
And I became very frightened about this, lest the king accuse me falsely.

text.title: Why should my countenance not be sad:

pasuk.text: [as translated,] why should my countenance not be sad.
Jerusalem, which is the place of the graves of my forefathers, is laid waste.

text.title: For what do you make request:

pasuk.text: What do you request of me and I shall do it for you.
And I said before the king in my prayer, “May it be Your will, O God of the heavens, that You fulfill my petition and my request.”
that you grant me permission to ascend to Jerusalem and build it.

text.title: And the king said to me:

pasuk.text: At the time the king spoke to me, his wife, the queen, was sitting beside him.

Heb. וְהַשֵּׁגָל, his wife the queen, as it is stated (Dan. 5:2): “… his queen (שֵּׁגְלָתֵהּ) and his concubine,” for it is customary for Scripture to write “the queen,” next to “the concubine” ; his wives and his concubines, like (Song 6:9): “ וּפִּילַגְשִּׁים מְלָכוֹת, queens and concubines.”

text.title: How long will your trip take:

pasuk.text: When is it your intention to return?
When is it your intention to return?
He gave me permission to go.

text.title: and I gave him a time:

pasuk.text: I gave him a time of return.

text.title: may letters be given to me:

pasuk.text: [Let] your scribes [give me letters] by your sanction and your knowledge, sealed with your signet to the governors of the land beyond the river, on the side of the land of Israel.
and escort me in peace.
to Jerusalem, which is in the province of Judea.
and that you send a letter to Asaph.

text.title: the guardian of the king’s orchard:

pasuk.text: He was appointed over the king’s forests.

This is the intensive conjugation: to make ceilings and beams for the gates of the castles of the Temple Mount, for they had built the Temple as it should be built, but the gates of the walls of the Temple Mount and the wall for the court surrounding the Temple had not yet been built.

text.title: and for the wall of the city:

pasuk.text: and to make beams for the wall of the city.

text.title: and for the house to which I shall go:

pasuk.text: and to make a house in which I shall dwell for my needs.
all I asked him for.
according to the hand of the Holy One, blessed be He, which was good upon me, to cause me to succeed.

text.title: and I gave them the king’s letters:

pasuk.text: in order that they escort me in peace.

text.title: officers of the army and horsemen:

pasuk.text: the king sent with me [officers] in my honor, in order that I go in peace.
When they heard that I had come to request good for Israel and to build the walls of Jerusalem it displeased them greatly, for they were the adversaries of Judah and Benjamin.

text.title: and I was there for three days:

pasuk.text: I was in Jerusalem for three days, and at the end of three days, I and a few men with me arose at night, and I did not tell any person what the Holy One, blessed be He, had put into my heart.

text.title: and there were no animals with me:

pasuk.text: The few men who were with me went by foot and I alone rode on an animal. They did not ride their horses because they wanted to leave the city in secret, without anyone knowing. They went to break and cast down the walls of the city at night and to increase their breaches in order that on the morrow, the people of the city would be eager and agree unanimously with Nehemiah to build the walls of the city. So it appears from the text.

text.title: And I went out through the Gate of the Valley:

pasuk.text: I went out through that gate at night with the men who were with me toward En Hattannin and the Dung Gate in the wall of the city; and I broke the wall, and the wall was easily cast down and broken because it had been burned with fire.
which are those places that were breached, and they breached them more.

text.title: And I passed to the Fountain Gate:

pasuk.text: And I wished to pass to those places in the wall of the city and in those breaches, and there was no place in those breaches for riders on animals to pass through because they were so small.
And I was ascending from one side at night, and I was breaking the wall with the men who were with me.
And when I returned, I came by way of the Gate of the Valley.
who were in the city did not know where I had gone to and what I had done.
Heb. כֵּן עַד, until now.
On the morrow I said to them.

text.title: and we shall no longer be a reproach:

pasuk.text: that our adversaries should not plunder and pillage us.
who gave me favor and success before the king.
They intended everything for good-to build the wall of the city and its towers.
When our adversaries heard the news of the building of the walls of the city, they mocked us.
Are you rebelling against the king by building the wall of the city in order to rebel against him?
What do you have in the building of the wall of this city, for you have no share in it.
Such was the name of the gate.
that gate with the sanctity of the city.
i.e., of the gate.

text.title: and until the Tower of the Hundred:

pasuk.text: Such was the name of the tower.
Next to it, near the Sheep’s Gate, each builder built.

Such was their custom, these would build here [their section] of the wall of the city until [the part] they were responsible for was completed, and then others would build next to the first construction. Such was their custom, one after another, until the entire wall was built.

As in (Num. 2:20) “Next to him, the tribe of Manasseh” , near him, and such is its explanation, next to the construction, and Scripture was not particular in its choice of words. Sometimes it says ודי לע, and sometimes it says וילו.“And next to them he repaired.”
Such was the name of the gate.
They placed the beams and ceilings on the gate.

Heb. קֵרוּהוּ the intensive conjugation, like “… behold he laid the beams (קֵרָה) ,” [which appears nowhere in Scripture;] similar to (Ps. 104: 3): “Who roofs (הַמְקָרֶה) His upper chambers with water.” The “kuf” of קֵרוּהוּ is not customarily vowelized with a “hirik” in this context because of the “resh” following it, like (ibid. 10:3): “blessed (בֵּרֵ) ” ; (Prov. 17:5): “blasphemed (חֵרֵף) ” ; (Gen. 17:16): “I shall bless her (וּבֵרַכְתִּיהָ) ” ;(Ezek. 29:12): “and I shall scatter them (וּזְרֵתִים) in the lands.”
מַנְעוּלָיו, ses verrous in French, its bolts (locks).
Heb. הֶחֱזִיק, [lit. strengthened,] to build the building.
They were called this because of their place, which was Tekoa.
the wealthy men of Tekoa.
They did not assist in the service of the Holy One, blessed be He, to build the wall of the city.

text.title: And… the gate of the old [city]:

pasuk.text: Heb. הַיְשָּׁנָה, the Gate Yeshana, such was its name.

text.title: a throne for the governor of the land beyond the river:

pasuk.text: The [people of] the land beyond the river built a throne for the governor of the land beyond the river to sit upon.
That family was called by their craft.
Heb. וַיַעַזְבוּ יְרוּשָּׁלַיִם They filled it with earth up to the wide wall in order to strengthen it.

text.title: the ruler of half the district of Jerusalem:

pasuk.text: He was the prince over half the people in Jerusalem. פֶּלֶ is an expression of a duchy or a kingdom.
his lot fell to build, for his house was near that place of the wall of the city.
Just like the measurement which his friend built before [him], so he also built like [his friend.]

in the building of the wall. The expression of measure is inappropriate for the building of the gates because they have [a measure] only in the building of a part of the wall, for we do not find in the entire chapter of the building of the gates the expression of a measure.
He also built a tower by that name. All these towers in the chapter were built in the wall around the city.
Shallum and his daughters repaired the building of the structure.
but the Dung Gate was not included.

text.title: the ruler of the district of Mizpah:

pasuk.text: the prince and duke of Mizpah.
he was building the same gate.
And he laid the roof on it, an expression of a ceiling (מְטַלַלְתָּא).

text.title: and the wall of the pool of Shelah:

pasuk.text: which inclines towards the king’s garden.
They recognized these places.
the name of a place.

From that bailiwick, the half district, he built this structure. In the word לְפִּלְכּוֹ, the “kaff” has a “dagesh,” as one says from מֶלֶ, מַלְכּוֹ, from עֶבֶד, עַבְדוֹ, so does one say from פֶּלֶ, פִּלְכּוֹ, for [if] the last letter of the noun is one of the letters “beth”, “gimmel”, “daleth”, “kaff”, “pey,” or “tav,” it is punctuated with a “dagesh.”
the Levites.

text.title: opposite the ascent to the armory:

pasuk.text: opposite the place where the mighty men would ascend to the weapons. According to the simple interpretation of the verse, it appears that there was a place near the wall where the mighty men kept their weapons, as it is stated: (II Kings 10:2) “… and cities (sic) of fortification and arms.”
at the corner of the wall.
Heb. הֶחֱרָה. Its interpretation is according to the context, and it is a double expression for repairing.

text.title: from the entrance of the house of Eliashib until the end of, etc.:

pasuk.text: Opposite that house he built his structure.
which was there near the wall.

text.title: and the tower that juts out:

pasuk.text: There was one tower in the wall that jutted out and protruded from within.

text.title: And the Nethinites dwelt in the Ophel:

pasuk.text: And the Nethinites were dwelling in that district, and they were building their district, which was near the wall, until opposite the Water Gate of the eastern side.

text.title: and the tower that juts out:

pasuk.text: There was a tower in the wall that jutted out and protruded from within.
Each one was building opposite his house.

text.title: and Hanun the sixth son of Zalaph:

pasuk.text: Zalaph had many sons, and Hanun was the sixth.
Heb. מִדָה שֵּׁנִי, like שֵּׁנִית.
Heb. נִשְּׁכָּתוֹ, like לִשְּׁכָּתוֹ. He had one chamber adjoining the wall.
the goldsmith, and he was named after his craft.

text.title: And between the ascent to the tower and the Sheep Gate:

pasuk.text: At the beginning of the building they began to build the Sheep Gate, as it says (verse 1): “… and they built the Sheep Gate, etc.” So did they build the wall all around, one after the other.

text.title: before his brethren and the army of Samaria:

pasuk.text: before his brethren and the army of Samaria, who were the adversaries of Judea.
Why are the Jews doing this?
Heb. הָאֲמֵלָלִים, a term denoting weakness and feebleness.
Do they think that the heathens will allow them to build?
Will they constantly slaughter their sacrifices for themselves as they think?

text.title: Will they finish in one day:

pasuk.text: Will they complete the work that they started in one day? That is to say that the heathens will not permit them to complete their building.
Will they revive and repair and restore stones to their previous state to be harder and stronger than the dust?
Heb. מֵעֲרֵמוֹת, a term denoting heaps and mounds.

The stones were burnt and have become dust. So did they jeer and ridicule the building of the wall, which they were building from the burnt stones that had fallen to the earth from the fire when Jerusalem was burned.

text.title: And Tobiah the Ammonite was beside him:

pasuk.text: Tobiah was beside Sanballat.
And so he was saying and ridiculing.
even this building that they are building.
on the building to breach the wall of the city, what will become of it? That is to say that the building cannot be repaired, and whoever wishes, can come and break into it.
When I heard their ridicule of us, I prayed this prayer.
that they be exiled from the land as we were exiled.
Heb. תְּכַס וְאַל, like וְאַל תְּכַסֶה, similar to (Prov. 25:9): “… but do not divulge (תְּגָל) another’s secret,” like תְּגַלֶה.
that they have provoked the builders to ridicule them.
Heb. וַתִּקָשֵּׁר, lit. it was bound. When the wall was bound up and built to its half, the people were eager and anxious to complete their building of it.
Heb. עָלְתָה אָרוּכָה, [lit. attained a cure,] that the wall was built.
A [word having the] meaning of bandaging and healing.

text.title: that the people who were exposed had commenced to be closed in:

pasuk.text: that the people of the city, who had heretofore been exposed without a wall, were now closed in by the building of the wall.
to wreak upon the building of the wall ruin and destruction. It is like (Isa. 32:5): “… and to speak destructively (תּוֹעָה) about the Lord.”
over the builders.
because of the enemies.
So were the people of Judea saying and complaining.
Those who bear and load the stones and the wood for the building of the wall have failed in their strength, for they have no more strength to build because of the enemies.
There is still much mud and clay to place into the wall, meaning that we still have much work, but we cannot build because of fear of the enemies.
Nehemiah proceeds to tell this.

text.title: They will not know, and they will not see:

pasuk.text: So were our adversaries saying about us: “They will not know, and the Israelites will not recognize us until we come suddenly into their midst and kill them, and with this plot we will stop and curtail the building.”

text.title: Now it came to pass when the Jews came:

pasuk.text: And now, the adversaries who had conspired together to wage war against us gathered with the Jews who were among them in their lands, and those Jews who had joined them came before the army, as is customary for soldiers to do, to speak to us, and in this manner the Jews conspired against the enemies. Now it came to pass when the Jews who dwelt beside them came, etc.

text.title: that they said to us ten times:

pasuk.text: Those Jews warned us as many as ten times to wage war against our enemies because they were coming to war. And this is what they said to us, “From all the places, etc.” From all those places where you will be scattered while building the wall, here and there, be careful to assemble until you return upon us together to wage war against us.

text.title: So I stationed from below… the wall:

pasuk.text: When I heard their words, I stationed [mighty men] from below that place around Jerusalem, from behind the wall of the city and on the bare rocks.
of the people, of the mighty men among them with their weapons, to fight against our enemies when they would come.

text.title: And I stationed from below, etc. and I stationed the people, etc.:

pasuk.text: This verse follows the pattern of (Exod. 4:9): “… and the water that you will take from the river will be… will become blood on the dry land;” (Ps. 92:10): “For behold, Your enemies, O Lord, for behold, Your enemies shall perish;” (Jud. 5:12): “Praise! Praise! Deborah. Praise! Praise! Utter a song;” (Ps. 115:1): “Not to us, O Lord, not to us.”

text.title: And I saw, and I arose:

pasuk.text: And when I saw the enemies coming, I arose to speak to the nobles and to the prefects to spur them to fight against our enemy.
Heb. עַל אֲחֵיכֶם, for the sake of your brethren.

text.title: that it had become known to us:

pasuk.text: that they were coming to fight against us.
We all returned from the place where we had gathered to meet the enemies, each one to his work in the building of the wall.

text.title: And it was from that day on:

pasuk.text: And from that day on, half the mighty men worked at the building of the wall, and the remaining half of the mighty men were armed with weapons to guard their brethren who were doing the work.
Heb. וְהָרְמָחִים. The “vav” is superfluous, like the “vav” of (Gen. 36:24): “And these are the sons of Zibeon: Aiah (וְאַיָה) and Anah.”
were close behind the entire tribe of Judah to be cautious in the battle.

text.title: The builders of the wall, etc.:

pasuk.text: Those who were building the wall and those who were loading and carrying the loads were working with one hand, and carrying weapons with the other.
Heb. הַשָּׁלַח, an implement of war, like (Job 33:18): "… from perishing by the sword (מֵעֲבֹר בַּשָּׁלַח). And so did Menahem associate it (Machbereth Menahem p. 174).
How were they building? They were all girded, each one with his sword on his waist, and thus did they build.
He was always beside me.
Heb. הַרְבֵּה, a great [amount of work].
[as translated,] will fight for us.

text.title: Let each man and his youth:

pasuk.text: each of the builders and a youth with him.

text.title: lodge in the midst of Jerusalem:

pasuk.text: And the night was for their watch, and [during] the day they were doing work. The result was that they did not sleep at all.

text.title: we did not take off our clothes:

pasuk.text: We were always zealous in guarding.

text.title: man took it even to the water:

pasuk.text: This refers back to “not” above, like (I Sam. 2:3): “… let not arrogance come out of your mouth.” None of us would take off his clothes to lie down or to wash them with water, and this is a double expression, [repeating,] we did not undress.
Heb. שִּׁלְחוֹ, taking off, like (Lev. 6:4): “He shall then take off his garments,” which is translated by Targum as וְיִשְּׁלַח.

text.title: Now the cry of the people and their wives was great:

pasuk.text: The poor people were crying exceedingly.
about their brothers, the rich Jews.

text.title: There were some who were saying:

pasuk.text: He gives a reason for his words: Why were they crying? Some of the poor people were saying, “We are many with our sons and daughters and have to buy corn. Now we will have to sell our sons and daughters in order to buy corn in order to live.” So were they crying about the rich Jews who did not wish to support them.

text.title: And there were some who were saying “Our fields, etc.”:

pasuk.text: And there were some among the poor who were complaining and saying “Our fields, vineyards and houses we shall give to others as a pledge and as security to buy corn for our food.”
since the rich do not give any of their property up to us for our support.

text.title: And there were some who were saying, “We have borrowed money”:

pasuk.text: And there were some who were saying, “We have already borrowed money from others on our fields and our vineyards to pay the king’s tax, and now we have nothing for our support.”
Heb. לְמִדַּת, for the king’s tax, like (Ezra 4:13): “… the king’s due (מִנְדָּה), the head tax, and the meal tax.”

text.title: And now, like the flesh of our brethren is our flesh:

pasuk.text: And now, we are as esteemed and distinguished as our brethren who are rich.

text.title: like their children are our children:

pasuk.text: Like their children, who are esteemed and distinguished, so are our children distinguished.
And now we have to subject and deliver our sons and daughters to others for the sake of our sustenance.

text.title: and some of our daughters are subjected:

pasuk.text: And already there are some of our daughters who are subjected to others in slavery.
We do not have the ability to redeem them.

text.title: and others have our fields and vineyards:

pasuk.text: We have even delivered our fields and vineyards to others for our sustenance. From now on, what shall we eat? We have nothing with which to sustain ourselves.

text.title: And I thought this over to myself:

pasuk.text: Heb. וַיִמָלֵ לִבִּי עָלַי, and my heart took counsel within myself.
I contended with the nobles and the prefects, who were the rich people.
Why are you doing this? You should have supported these poor people, but you are lending them money in order to appropriate their sons and daughters, their fields, vineyards and houses.

text.title: and I gathered a large assembly around them:

pasuk.text: I congregated and gathered a large assembly around them to shout at them in order to embarrass them.
And so I said to them: We already bought our Jewish brethren who were in captivity from the heathens to whom they were sold.

text.title: with as much as we could afford:

pasuk.text: with as much money as was in our hands.
And you too will sell to the heathens your brethren who are subjected to you as slaves?

text.title: and they will be sold to us:

pasuk.text: And the result will be that they will be sold to us by the heathens (and if so, why should you sell them, since we will be compelled to redeem them? This is found in certain editions).
They were silent and ashamed, and they did not know what to answer.
The thing is evil in the eyes of the Holy One, blessed be He.
because of the reproach of the heathens who are our enemies.

text.title: I, too, and my brothers and my servants:

pasuk.text: I, too, and my colleagues lent them money, and we shall abandon and relinquish to them all these loans.
Heb. נֹשִׁים, like (II Kings 4:1): “… and the creditor (וְהַנֹשֶּׁה) has come to take.”
And you shall also do as I do, to relinquish all their debts to them.
and the large amount of money that they owe you with the corn and the wine, etc.
And they said [that they were willing] to return and to relinquish all.

text.title: to do according to this promise:

pasuk.text: that they too should relinquish.

text.title: I also shook out my garment:

pasuk.text: Heb. חָצְנִי, I also shook out my garment. חָצְנִי is like (Isa. 49:22): “… and they shall bring your sons on the skirt of their garments (בְּחֹצֶן).”
is escrol(l)e in Old French, I shook out, like (ibid. 52:2): “Shake yourself (הִתְנַעֲרִי) from the dust.”
So shall the Holy One, blessed be He, shake out from the world and from their property those who do not relinquish their debts.
without property.
i.e., the king.
Heb. פֶּחָם, like פֶּחָה, ruler, after the pattern of רֵיקָם, empty, like רֵיקָה.
of King Darius, for then he ascended from Babylon, as it is stated (2:1): “Now it came to pass in the month of Nissan in the twentieth year, etc.”
which equal twelve years.
I and my colleagues who came with me.

text.title: have not eaten the food allotted to the governor:

pasuk.text: the food that was fit for the governor, which the people give the governor from the tax.
Heb. הִכְבִּידוּ, lit. made heavy. They made the tax heavy upon the people.
They would take bread and wine from them for the tax after they had already given forty silver shekels, and they were accustomed to doing this every year.
[i.e., the servants] of the governors.
the wall of the city.
I busied myself to engage in it constantly.

text.title: and we did not buy a field:

pasuk.text: But neither I nor my associates bought the fields of the Jews who were building the wall because of their poverty; they were engaged in building the wall, but I gave them money in order to build the wall.
to build constantly.
were eating at my table, in addition to the proselytes who came to us from the gentiles, for they too were eating at my table.
And every day they ate at my table one ox, six sheep and many birds.
Heb. בְּרֻרוֹת. Its interpretation is according to the context: six prepared sheep, like the matter that is stated (I Sam. 25:18): “… five prepared (עֲשׂוּיוֹת) sheep.”
Heb. נַעֲשּׂוּ, an expression of preparation, like (Gen. 18:8): “… and the calf that he had prepared (עָשָּׂה).”

text.title: and as much as ten days’ supply:

pasuk.text: Heb. וּבֵין עֲשֶּׂרֶת יָמִים, lit. and between ten days. And every day they drank much wine, the amount that suffices for ten days.
Heb. וְעִם זֶה; and this procedure, for which I used to make such big expenditures.
of the tax, which is fit for the governor, I did not seek, and I did not request it of the people, for the work of the building of the wall was heavy and strong upon them.

pasuk.text: in the wall of the city.
that doors were not made in the gates of the city.

against me. I understood from them that they were plotting against me to assassinate me there.

in that letter.

pasuk.text: that it is known to all the nations that you and all the Jews are plotting to rebel.
Gashmu is Geshem the Arab, and its interpretation is like a man who says to his friend, “This is the matter, and so-and-so says.”
This refers back to the text, and it is a transposed verse. It is as though it was written, “According to these words was heard among the nations, etc.”
Until “… and take counsel together” was written in the letter.

who say that there is a king in Judea.

pasuk.text: After you have been called king, it will be reported to the king according to these words.
Heb. כִּי. This כִּי is in place of אֶלָּא, but.
contro(u)ves eles in Old French; you are concocting them, like (I Kings 12:33): “… that he had fabricated (בָּדָה) from his heart.”

text.title: for they are coming to assassinate you:

pasuk.text: for Sanballat and his colleagues will come to assassinate you.

Therefore, he warned him to enter the Temple and to close the doors about himself, because the doors of the gates of the city had not been made, as it says at the beginning of the chapter (verse 1): “Also that until that time, I had not erected doors in the gates.”

text.title: Will a man like me flee:

pasuk.text: This is a question: Will a man like me flee to enter the Temple?
I will not enter there because of fear of death, and I will not transgress the commandments of the Holy One, blessed be He, that a stranger (a non-Kohen) may not enter His Temple.
I discerned in his words that the Holy One, blessed be He, had not sent him on this mission, but that he wanted me to commit a transgression because of fear of death.

text.title: for he spoke prophesy concerning me:

pasuk.text: for he spoke these words concerning me in the name of prophecy.
Heb. שְּׂכָרוֹ. Each one of them had hired him and given him pay to frighten me and to curtail the building of the wall.
he told me these things.
in order that I fear them, to do this to enter the Temple and sin.

text.title: so that they should have this for a scandal:

pasuk.text: in order that they should have this as a scandal to reproach me with this sin.
She and the rest of the false prophets received pay from Sanballat and his cohorts in order to frighten me with their false prophecies.
day of the month of Ellul, in the twentieth year of King Darius, for in the twentieth year of Darius, Nehemiah went up from Babylon, and in that year he built the ruins of Jerusalem.
The construction of the wall was completed fifty-two days after they had started building it.

text.title: Now it came to pass when all our enemies heard:

pasuk.text: this matter, that the construction of the wall was completed.

text.title: that all the nations became frightened:

pasuk.text: when all the nations saw that the construction of the wall of the city had been completed.

text.title: and they fell very low in their own eyes:

pasuk.text: They themselves fell in their own eyes; they despised themselves, for the fear of the Jews had fallen upon them.
Heb. חֹרֵי, the princes of Judea.
Heb. עַל-טוֹבִיָה. He was a renegade Israelite.
i.e., Tobiah’s letters.

Tobiah [was the son-in-law] of Shechaniah.
[the son] of Tobiah.
Meshullam was a great man and a ruler.

Heb. טוֹבֹתָיו ses proezes, in Old French, his gallant exploits.
to tell Tobiah.

to guard the gates of Jerusalem.
Heb. מֵרַבִּים, lit. from many; from many days.
until midday, for the day was long.

And as long as the doors are open, they shall stand; they shall not move until the doors are locked shut, and whoever wishes to leave may leave the city, and whoever wishes to enter may come and enter. They did all this because of the enemies.
They should hold the doors to lock them.

text.title: watches among the inhabitants of Jerusalem:

pasuk.text: of the inhabitants of Jerusalem station watches, jetes in Old French, (groups of) watchmen.
Heb. רַחֲבַת יָדַיִם, a wide and large place.
Heb. לְהִתְיַחֵישׂ, to search for their lineage.

text.title: those who went up at first:

pasuk.text: of those Jews who went up with Ezra at first.

text.title: and I found written in it:

pasuk.text: All these words were written in that letter.

text.title: These are the people of the province, etc.:

pasuk.text: until (10:35): “And we cast lots for the wood sacrifice.”
to the province of Judea.

This is Joshua the son of Jehozadak, the High Priest. These figures sometimes coincide with the above figures (Ezra 2); sometimes there are some that do not coincide. Scripture was not so exact with the figures, but the total is the same in both places, as it is stated (Ezra 2:64, Neh. 7:66): “The entire congregation together was forty-two thousand three hundred and sixty.” The writer relied on this total and was not so exact in the figures of the individual numbers. Everything is explained above (Ezra 2).

text.title: on the first day of the seventh month:

pasuk.text: That is the day of Rosh Hashanah.
of the beginning of the day.

text.title: to the Scroll of the Law:

pasuk.text: All the people inclined their ears.
That wooden tower was made for the purpose of reading the Scroll of the Law upon it.

text.title: for he was above all the people:

pasuk.text: Therefore, they all saw him.

text.title: and when he opened it, all the people stood:

pasuk.text: And when he opened it to read, all the people stood silent.
Heb. עָמְדוּ, an expression of silence (they stood silent), like (Job 32:16): “… for they remained silent (עָמְדוּ) ; they no longer answered.”

text.title: with the uplifting of their hands:

pasuk.text: with the raising of their hands, meaning that they lifted their hands on high to thank the Holy One, blessed be He, as it is stated: (I Kings 8:22): “… and spread forth his hands towards heaven.”
meaning that they would translate the words of the Torah to the people.
meaning that they were standing on their feet.
Heb. וְשּׂם שֶׂכֶל, and giving wisdom; וְשּׂם is an expression of doing.
because it is the day of Rosh Hashanah.

text.title: for all the people were weeping:

pasuk.text: because they did not uphold the Torah appropriately.
to a poor man who has no food prepared for himself.
They admonished all the people to be quiet, that they should weep no longer.
Heb. הַסוּ, an expression of silence, like (Num. 13:30): “And Caleb hushed (וַיַהַס).”
of Rosh Hashanah.

And they commanded that they announce that they celebrate the Festival of Sukkoth, and so it is customary for Scripture to speak in this manner, like (I Sam. 9:27): “Tell the servant and he will go ahead of us.”
It is explained in Tractate Succah (12a) that this is a wild myrtle which is unfit for the lulav and only fit to make a sukkah.

every day.

and from their wives of the heathen nations, as is stated above (Ezra 10).

text.title: on the step of the Levites:

pasuk.text: There were steps upon which the Levites would stand when they would recite their song [for the sacrificial service].
From the beginning of the world until its end, He shall be blessed.

text.title: and they shall bless Your glorious Name:

pasuk.text: Now the Levites spoke toward the Shechinah in prayer, for He is great and exalted over every blessing and praise, for all the blessings and praises are His. Another explanation is that He is exalted above every blessing and praise; that no creature can bless Him or praise Him according to His greatness and His exaltedness, for He is exalted and raised higher than the mouth can express.
Heb. וְשַּׂמְתָּ. The accent is on the first syllable on the “sin,” because its meaning is in the past tense.
Heb. וְכָרוֹת, lit. and cutting, an expression of doing.
Heb. הֵזִידוּ, that they dealt wickedly, like (Exod. 18: 11): “… that they plotted (זָדוּ) against them.”
Heb. שֵּׁם, renom in French, renown.
every day.

Heb. לִרְעָבָם. From רָעָב one says לִרְעָבָם, as from צָמָא [one says] לִצְמָאָם.
with an oath, like (Exod. 6:8): “… which I raised My hand to give it.”

delicacies to the kings of the nations…

text.title: whom You have appointed over us:

pasuk.text: who rule over us.
Despite all the evil that has come upon us, we are making a trust with the Holy One, blessed be He, to believe and to trust in Him.
And we are writing on a scroll to accept His kingdom upon us in order that it be to us as a testimony.
for most of the great and prominent men among us have signed the scroll of the acceptance of the commandments, to be for us as a testimony.
He now proceeds to enumerate the signatories on the testimonial document of the acceptance of the commandments.

It is one name, and this is what I explained (Ezra 2: 63) that [the name] Hattirshatha refers to Nehemiah. And why was he called Hattirshatha? Because the Sages permitted him to drink wine of gentiles, because he was the butler of the king.
These are the proselytes who separated themselves from the practice of the nations to cling and attach themselves to the Law of the Holy One, blessed be He, and to keep His commandments.
Heb. עַל אֲחֵיהֶם with their brothers.
the great ones among them.
Heb. שֶּׁבֶר, grain, like (Gen. 47:14): “… for the grain (בַּשֶּׁבֶר) that they were purchasing.”
This refers to festivals.

text.title: and we shall abandon during the seventh year:

pasuk.text: As is stated (Exod. 23:11): “But throughout the seventh year you shall let it go and abandon it (וּנְטַשְּׁתָּה).”

text.title: and the loan given by every hand:

pasuk.text: This refers to the release of loans during the seventh year.

pasuk.text: to do with money.

pasuk.text: The first of every fruit of a tree. They are required by rabbinical injunction.

text.title: we shall bring to the priests to the chambers:

pasuk.text: for they were usually there.

pasuk.text: who take their tithes in all the cities of Israel.

text.title: the head to begin the thanksgiving in prayer:

pasuk.text: He was the head and the appointed official, and the greatest one who was first to start and to thank in prayer and in singing the songs of the Levites. יְהוֹדֶה is like יוֹדֶה, and the “hey” enters the word unnecessarily, like יוֹסֵף and יְהוֹסֵף.

pasuk.text: appointed over the Levites in Jerusalem.

pasuk.text: He was appointed over the work of the Temple, such as the buildings of the repair of the Temple and the rest of the matters for which money is spent for the work of the Temple, like the matter that is stated above (verse 16): “… and Shabbethai and Jazabad over the outside work, etc.”

text.title: For the command of the king was upon them and [his] trust:

pasuk.text: The king trusted them.
to spend money from King Darius’s treasury.

text.title: there were divisions to Judah and to Benjamin:

pasuk.text: They were divided into their divisions here and there in the land of Judah and Benjamin.
That is Joshua the High Priest.
i.e., those who were leaders in the days of Joshua the High Priest.
[This was] a type of musical instrument which accompanied the songs.
as we find (in I Chronicles from ch. 24 on) that the Levites were divided into twenty-four watches.
All those [listed] in this verse were high priests.

text.title: And in the days of Joiakim:

pasuk.text: who was the high priest. These priests were the leaders of the fathers’ houses of their watches.

Of the watch of Seraiah, the head of the father’s house was Meraiah, and of the watch of Jeremiah, the head of the father’s house was Hananiah, and so it is with them all, and the reason Scripture did not list all twenty-four watches is that it is not exacting in enumerating them all.

text.title: The Levites in the days of Eliashib:

pasuk.text: These Levites were the heads of the fathers’ houses in the watches of the Levites in the days of Eliashib the High Priest, and the priests enumerated immediately above were the heads of the fathers’ houses in their watches, also in the days of Eliashib.
This matter came about in the days of Darius.

text.title: even until the days of Johanan:

pasuk.text: All those who were the heads of the fathers’ houses of the Levites until the days of Johanan the High Priest were enumerated in the chronicles.
for they were divided into their watches to recite the song.

text.title: sentries of the gates [in their] watch:

pasuk.text: The sentries of the gates were in their watch to guard the gates of the Temple.
Heb. בַּאֲסֻפֵּי, like בְּסִיפֵּי הַשְּׁעָרִים, at the thresholds of the gates.

text.title: These were in the days of Joiakim:

pasuk.text: These were the gate sentries in the days of Joiakim.

text.title: And in the dedication of the wall of Jerusalem:

pasuk.text: at the completion of the wall of the city, to sanctify the city.

the singers came from [the plain] surrounding Jerusalem.
First they purified themselves, and afterwards they purified the others.

text.title: and the gates and the wall:

pasuk.text: that there should be no uncleanliness in the city.

meaning that he sanctified the city, the princes, the tribunal, and the Levites with two thanksgiving offerings around the city, as is delineated in Tractate Shebuoth (14a, 15a, b), in order to sanctify the city.
two breads of the thanksgiving offerings, each bread being called a thanksgiving offering.

the colleagues of Zechariah the priest.
Before the Fountain Gate, they marched around the city.
And before them they ascended from the Fountain Gate to the steps of the City of David, and those steps led to the wall.

text.title: And the second thanksgiving offering, which went opposite [it]:

pasuk.text: The other thanksgiving offering, which was second to its fellow, went opposite its fellow, alongside it, not one following the other.
And I marched after it, [i.e.,] after the thanksgiving offering.
They stood, there and did not go any further.
that they carried to the Temple.

Heb. מְנָאוֹת like מָנוֹת.

pasuk.text: The priests were taking what was due them and the Levites what was due them.
and ministered there before the Holy One, blessed be He, with thanksgiving offerings and thanksgivings.

pasuk.text: And they would give the tithe to the Levites, who would take the tithe from the tithe and give it to the priests.
Every mixture of heathens, like (Exodus 12:38): “A great mixed multitude (עֵרֶב רַב) also went up with them.”
Heb. וְלִפְנֵי מִזֶה, before this.

pasuk.text: the gifts due the Levites.
during this entire episode.
when I returned to Babylon.
to give me permission to go up and to return to Jerusalem.

that the Israelites had not placed the gifts there, and because of that they fled and wandered here and there to ask for their gifts, and were not occupied as much with their service.

to distribute the gifts among them [the Levites].
sheaves of grain.

text.title: on the day they sold provisions:

pasuk.text: On the day they were selling food and provisions. צָיִד, provisions, as (Gen. 45:21): “… and he gave them provision (צֵדָה) for the way.”
Merchants of Tyre would bring fish to sell.

text.title: Now it came to pass when the gates of Jerusalem cast shadows:

pasuk.text: When the shadows of the Sabbath eve fell on the gates, I ordered the doors of the city to be closed and not re-opened until after the Sabbath so that the traffickers would not enter the city to sell their merchandise and cause Israel to profane the Sabbath.
The traffickers and the merchants lodged outside Jerusalem on the Sabbath once and twice so that the Children of Israel would open the gates and buy from them on the Sabbath.
I warned those traffickers.
if you continue to do this a second time.
From that day on, they did not come on the Sabbath day.
who had married heathen wives.
Many of their children spoke the Ashdodite language like their mothers.
I gave them lashes in order to chastise them and remind them.

If he sinned, how much more so is it certain that you will sin through your heathen wives! As is written in the next verse, “Shall we hearken, etc.?” i.e., Solomon was found sinning through his heathen wives, and you have married foreign wives in order to sin?

text.title: And [one] of the sons of Joiada… was the son in law of Sanballat:

pasuk.text: One of the sons of Joiada was the son- in-law of Sanballat, the adversary of the Jews; thus, I drove him away from me so that he should not frequent Jerusalem because of his son-in-law, to see the city and the ways to enter and leave it.
the good that they did.
They would cut wood for the altar pyre at appointed times.
that they should bring the first fruits at a certain time; for each species I appointed its time.
